awards.title: Business Panel Competition - Winner
awards.description: As a team of six students, we won the 2019 Business Panel Competition by consulting multinational insurance and asset management company AEGON on how to capitalize on future legislative changes in the German corporate pension scheme market. A total of 45 teams participated in this competition.

awards.title: IB Freshman of the Year Award 2016/2017 - Winner
awards.description: In August 2017, I was pronounced winner of the Freshman of the Year Award within the bachelor's degree in International Business over the year 2016-2017 for obtaining the highest GPA among 351 students.

projects.title: Knowledge System Development to Enhance Employee Utilization Efficiency
projects.description: Our team developed a knowledge system for the ‘Wet ‘n Wild’ restaurant—located in Alphen aan den Rijn—that provides an effective estimation of the number of employees that are required to be scheduled to work on any specific day of the week. The first stage of the project revolved around eliciting process knowledge about the manner in which the number of required employees is generally determined within the operations of the restaurant. This respective knowledge was elicited during a series of interviews with knowledge experts within the restaurant, and was used to compose a number of formal deliverables on the ‘as-is’ current state operations that are performed to determine how many employees are required to be scheduled. These deliverables were used as input in the second stage of the project, which revolved around the actual development and implementation of the knowledge system. The respective system was constructed using Prolog, a programming language that can be instructed to retrieve specific output using logical expressions and corresponding input data. The main variables that were considered in our knowledge system were (1) the specific day of interest (i.e. a regular weekday or during the weekend), (2) the weather forecast, (3) the number of reservations at the restaurant, (4) hosted events (e.g. weddings, business meetings, etc.), (5) nearby events (e.g. externally hosted local events), and (6) contemporary COVID-19 regulations. Furthermore, in determining the required number of scheduled employees, our system was able to differentiate between four different types of employees: (1) supervisors, (2) bartenders, (3) ‘wijklopers’, and (4) ‘runners’.

projects.title: FairSight Dashboard – Improving AI Ethics Compliance in Corporate Recruitment
projects.description: Present day artificial intelligence (AI) applications that are employed in corporate recruitment do not always assign equalized odds and/or equal opportunity to members of every group of society. Such systemic algorithmic bias typically originates from underlying systemic bias in training data, and could lead to deficient recruitment of personnel. It could even lead to substantial public backlash whenever  such systemic bias is deemed sensitive by the community. Recognizing the social delicacy that surrounds the employment of AI applications in corporate recruitment, our team introduced a prototype dashboard—dubbed ‘FairSight’—which aims to assist recruiters in making (more) unbiased and non-discriminatory decisions. The main strength of the dashboard is that it can detect and subsequently neutralize the effects of demographic characteristics in application documents, but FairSight also adheres to the principles of explainable AI (XAI) by graphically disclosing the manner in which the most suitable applicants are identified (in contrast to the conventional ‘black box’ metaphor that is generally used to describe algorithmic operations). Given the ever increasing public attention surrounding AI ethics—specifically, algorithmic fairness—we are opinionated that the foundational principles of FairSight can serve as cornerstone for future AI applications in corporate recruitment.

projects.title: COVID-19 Social Distancing Sentiment Analysis Using Twitter Data
projects.description: Our team was interested in capturing the general public opinion of the Dutch population regarding the COVID-19 concept of social distancing. To do so, we preprocessed roughly 80,000 tweets—all of which were in Dutch—that featured any concept related to COVID-19. We subsequently used a regex query to identify the tweets that were of interest to us within the context of our research (around 5,000 units). We used an application of the Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) algorithm to construct the graphics that visually clustered the topics that were most-frequently discussed within the tweets of interest.

projects.title: Robot in a Maze – Training Agents Using Reinforcement Learning Algorithms
projects.description: Using the Q-learning and SARSA reinforcement learning algorithms, our team was able to construct and train two agents that were able to autonomously solve the classic ‘Robot in a Maze’ problem. In this problem, an agent is repeatedly dropped at random locations in the (virtual) environment at hand (a 15x15 maze), and it subsequently tries to find the exit by repeatedly moving around the maze (and thus learning about its environment). Not only were we able to train the agents to constantly successfully find the exit, but we were also able to reach a local optimum in performance by tweaking the model parameters according to the performance data of our agents. This was a fun project, but I believe that, when adopting a perspective that exceeds the boundaries of this project, reinforcement learning algorithms are showing very much potential within the field of automized decision-making.

projects.title: B Lab – ArchiMate Business Layer Model of the B Impact Assessment
projects.description: B Lab is one of the leading agencies in the field of ethical, social, and environmental accounting. Whenever a company meets the standards of its B Impact Assessment, it becomes eligible for bearing the title of ‘B Corporation’ and is awarded appropriate certification. Using an elaborate textual description provided by B Lab of its assessment activities, including pre- and post-assessment activities such as application-specific and certification-specific activities, I was able to construct a corresponding graphic model of the overarching B Impact Assessment process flow according to the ArchiMate business layer principles.

projects.title: Online Movie Platform Project
projects.description: We figured it would be fun to develop an online movie platform which resembled existing platforms such as IMDb and Rotten Tomatoes. To do so, we designed an XML schema which conceptually specified each of the movie attributes of interest (e.g. ‘director’, ‘runtime’, ‘lead actor’, etc.) that we wanted to display on our platform. Thereafter, we made a list of our favorite movies (around 25 in total, mostly Quentin Tarantino and Christopher Nolan), and we composed the XML instance document which contained all of the respective attributes. We ended up locally hosting our platform using a custom XSLT sheet which rendered the corresponding HTML. We used a basic CSS stylesheet for the platform design.

projects.title: Resource Allocation Optimalization – Strategic Planning Model Development
projects.description: Having access to an external dataset that contained around 15,000 observations of individual medical activities within the overarching process of Sepsis (i.e. blood poisoning) treatment in an unspecified hospital, our team was able to develop a model that facilitated the strategic allocation of the hospital’s (human) resources over the 16 activities which comprised the overarching treatment process. Our final model was compatible with the format of the data originating from the hospital’s ERP. Therefore, we believe that our model could provide real-time strategic suggestions on the allocation of (human) resources within the hospital if it were integrated with the respective ERP.

projects.title: Nederlandse Spoorwegen – Ticket Vending Machine Software Design Proposal
projects.description: During the time of this project, the Nederlandse Spoorwegen (NS), which is the principal passenger railway operator in The Netherlands, was drawing up plans concerning the implementation of its next generation of ticket vending machines. Our team was invited to develop and introduce a conceptual software design which encompassed the interaction between the various hardware and (third-party) software components that comprised the new machine. Transcripts of various interviews with a broad range of NS personnel (including the project manager, software architects, and system maintenance employees) were made available, from which we were able to derive a fully-dressed use case, including requirements concerning (1) functionality, (2) usability, (3) reliability metrics, (4) performance metrics, and (5) future supportability. We constructed a UML class diagram in order to graphically communicate our software design, since it enabled us to clearly display the abstract responsibilities, attributes, and the supported methods of the software components. Our design was focused on adhering to the principles of loose coupling and high cohesion, which greatly enhanced the reusability of the components in the design. Additionally, our aim was to develop a design which was robust to future changes in both functional and nonfunctional requirements. The main challenge that we encountered during the development of the design was the integration with the legacy price computation system and the corresponding data from the MySQL Oracle Enterprise server.

projects.title: Information System Design and Implementation
projects.description: In this project, I designed and implemented an information system that supported the following processes of an academic-level educational institution: (1) student application process, (2) student curriculum selection process, (3) course enrollment management, (4) teaching position vacancy publication process, (5) teaching position applications management, (6) filing of student grades, and (7) student graduation process. All individual processes are interconnected in the information system and collectively form an overarching process. I used the ProcessMaker workflow software to design and implement the information system. ProcessMaker is BPMN-based workflow software which provides amazing simulation opportunities regarding the interactions between different groups of actors within the overarching process. I used the PHP server-side scripting language to write conditional instructions for the information system, and SQL was used to store/retrieve data in/from the tables in the database. I used MS Access to compose a database structure diagram, given that such a functionality is not covered in ProcessMaker.

projects.title: ‘Boodschappelijk’ – Mobile Platform Development Project
projects.description: I was project leader of a seven-member team which, in addition to myself, consisted of two developers, one UX and UI designer, and three additional support members. Drawing inspiration from the COVID-19 social distancing guidelines, our team developed the ‘Boodschappelijk’ mobile application which facilitated the contactless transfer of groceries between two groups of target users: volunteers and the elderly. Conducting the cooperative evaluations with numerous members of the two groups of target users proved to be a vital element of the development process of the application, since we were able to obtain valuable insights as to whether our design accounted for the physical and cognitive impairments that the elderly may experience. The mobile application was developed in Eclipse IDE (Java) by the development team in parallel with the aforementioned stages of the overarching development process. Additional documentation included (1) a business plan, which highlighted the (financial) opportunities the mobile platform could exploit, (2) a target group analysis, (3) a conceptual design specification, (4) an interaction design specification, (5) a visual design i.e. lo-fi prototype, and (6) an overview of corresponding personas, scenarios, and use case analyses.

projects.title: UMC Utrecht – Task Management System Development Project
projects.description: Our team was involved in the development of an internal task management system at the University Medical Center (UMC) Utrecht. During the course of the project, we collaborated closely with medical staff of various disciplines at the UMC Utrecht and the development team at consultancy firm Finaps through a series of interviews and presentations. Before anything else, we performed several requirements engineering activities and interviews with the medical staff in order to determine the desired functionalities and interaction design of the task management system. The feedback we received from the client and the development team helped us to refine the initial conceptual design specification, and a corresponding hi-fi prototype was developed accordingly. The hi-fi prototype consisted of a fully-interactive HTML document which contained all desired functionalities as specified by the UMC Utrecht medical staff.

projects.title: Search Engine Development Project
projects.description: My teammate and I developed a search engine by reconstructing the algebraic properties of the vector space model in the Spyder IDE, an application subset of the Anaconda open-source Python distribution. In short, the vector space model is used in machine learning for information retrieval purposes, in which cosine distance represents the similarity between the query-vector and one document-vector. The cosine distance is subsequently used as the metric of comparison in ranking the documents according to their relevance to the query at hand. We used articles from various online news portals (e.g. The New York Times, The Guardian, BBC, etc.), which were converted into CSV files and manually uploaded to the directory which was used by the search engine during its operations. The search engine was made accessible by using an external CSS design which, among other elements, contained (1) a search box for querying and (2) a ranked search output consisting of the top-10 documents and their corresponding cosine distance metrics.

projects.title: Webstore Design Principles Consultation Project
projects.description: Our team was requested to consult online retailer ‘ShopSec’—the actual name of the client was withheld from us—on the UI and UX design of its webstore. Design principles and contemporary trends found in academic literature were used in positing hypotheses for our experiment. The validity of the hypotheses was tested in the consumer behavior experiment, which consisted of an extensive survey in which the effects of various webstore design principles on consumers was investigated. The results of the experiment were analyzed and a consultation report was composed accordingly. We were able to include a list of 33 specific recommendations regarding the UI and UX design of ShopSec’s webstore in the overall consultation report. Additionally, we developed a prototype webstore in which the recommendations found in our consultation report were demonstrated. A custom CSS script was used to format the layout of the webstore.

projects.title: AEGON – Foreign Direct Investment Strategy Proposal
projects.description: This project was associated with the 2019 Business Panel Competition, which was jointly organized by the University of Groningen and multinational insurance and asset management company AEGON. A total of 45 teams were invited to submit and present a strategic proposal on how AEGON would be able to capitalize on legislative changes in the German corporate pension scheme market. In short, these respective legislative changes led to corporate pension schemes becoming more accessible to SMEs, and the people at AEGON’s Workplace Solutions were interested in our outlook on whether entering this market would be viable or not. Our proposal consisted of a thorough host country analysis, which was subdivided into individual analyses regarding (1) resource and competency requirements, (2) market conditions and corresponding level of competition, and (3) a cultural analysis concerning German consumer behavior in terms of obtaining pension plans. Using the findings of our analyses, we were able to develop a multi-faceted, quantitative analysis of the expected effectiveness of various foreign direct investment (FDI) strategies. The (partial) acquisition of an established German (native) pension scheme provider was determined to be the expected most effective FDI strategy. Additionally, we composed a shortlist of acquisition target companies based on (1) availability of desired resources and capabilities, (2) transferability of these respective resources, and (3) acquisition and integration feasibility. Our team made it into the final, and we eventually won the competition with our strategic proposal.

projects.title: Research on Foreign Direct Investment Opportunities in Mexico
projects.description: Our team spent three months researching the viability of exploiting the foreign direct investment (FDI) opportunity represented by having assembly line production—specifically within the automotive industry—being performed in local Mexican production plants. We conducted in-depth analyses of Mexico’s local resource endowments (natural, human, and intellectual) that were relevant to the industry of interest, as well as the host country institutional environment (i.e. governmental, legal, financial, and cultural properties). The results of these analyses enabled us to constructed a coherent overview of the comparative advantages, as well as the expected challenges, of moving assembly line production to Mexico. Using our findings, we were able to provide corresponding recommendations on the expected effectiveness of a wide range of entry strategies. What was interesting about this project was we were requested to compose two reports, the first report being written from the perspective of a neutral auditing organization, and the second report being written from the perspective of Mexico’s Secretariat of Economy with the aim to persuade automotive corporations to transfer their production operations into Mexico.

projects.title: Crocs – Novel Target Market Identification and Entry Strategy Proposal
projects.description: During the time of this project, footwear manufacturer Crocs was interested in our team’s perspective on the availability of potentially promising market space which up till then was left unexplored by the company. Our team observed that the key players in the market for semipro surfing gear considered the respective market as inferior, and that they were rather devoted to their endeavors in other clothing industries. This observation went hand in hand with the assertion that the market for semipro surfing gear showed little levels of fierce competition, leading us to believe that this was the blue ocean that Crocs had been looking for. Our perspective was amplified by the observation that Crocs’ current international operations were largely in coastal countries, which harmonizes with the target audience in the semipro surfing gear market. In order to lower the entry barrier as much as possible, we proposed a product portfolio that reaped the advantage of Crocs’ ‘Croslite’ propriety material. The products in the proposed portfolio were predominantly manufactured with the Croslite material, which implied that the company did not have to spend outrageous amounts of financial resources on R&D in order to produce the products that would allow them to enter the target market. Our proposal received broad support during the final presentation of the project.

profile_positions.description: The OGD shared service desk (SSD) teams provide effective IT support and integration solutions to external organizations. Specifically, our team was delivering full end-user support within large healthcare institutions in The Netherlands. Working in this fast-paced environment, I have been able to put my existing knowledge into practice, as well as having been able to gain additional experience in effectively approaching and resolving challenges from both a user and a corporate perspective.
profile_positions.title: SSD Member

profile_positions.description: I have been with HRpm (Roots) as a general employee in both temporary and non-temporary site construction. HRpm days consist of early mornings and hard work, but to see a complete festival site being constructed in only five days is a very rewarding experience.
profile_positions.title: General Employee
